newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Palestinian, Israeli violence in absence of talks.
newsitem.headline: Palestinian, Israeli violence in absence of talks.

text.p: Israelis and Palestinians have descended once more into violence now that the latest bid -- this time by Egypt -- to return them to substantive peace talks seems to be foundering.

Fifteen Palestinians and two Israeli soldiers were wounded on Sunday in the second day of clashes between troops and stone-throwing Arab demonstrators in the West Bank town of Hebron, witnesses and hospital officials said.
The two days of Hebron clashes followed unrest in Gaza on Thursday in which Israeli soldiers and a Jewish settler shot and wounded four Palestinians.
"I think that there is an organising hand and there is a political intent behind it...and it will not work," Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said of the violence.

Palestinian President Yasser Arafat told reporters after meeting co-Nobel peace laureate and former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in Ramallah: "There's a deep crisis in the peace process caused by the Israeli government's refusal to implement the (peace) agreement."
Peace negotiations between the sides ground to a halt in March when Netanyahu gave the go-ahead for construction of a new Jewish settlement in Arab East Jerusalem.

Palestinians demand settlement building stop before they will resume substantive negotiations. They say it pre-empts final peace talks on Jerusalem and the West Bank. Netanyahu vows the building will go on.

Palestinians have been further angered by a non-binding U.S. House of Representatives vote last week saying Jerusalem, the Arab eastern half of which Israel captured and annexed in 1967 in a move not recognised by the international community, must remain Israel's undivided capital.
Egypt in late May stepped into a mediating breach left after the United States, the official peace process sponsor, failed to resolve the crisis.
On Thursday, Egyptian envoy Osama el-Baz shuttled between Netanyahu and Arafat in his latest bid to solve the impasse. He returned to Egypt saying more work was needed to end the crisis.
Palestinian peace negotiators headed for Cairo on Sunday evening ahead of Monday talks with el-Baz and Foreign Minister Amr Moussa on salvaging peacemaking.
The Palestinian Authority has made clear it feels time is running out. In a statement issued after the weekly cabinet meeting chaired by Arafat at week's end, it said:

"The Palestinian public was patient for a long time over the accelerating Israeli trespasses and violations and Netanyahu's affirmations on continuing the settlement attacks. They cannot be patient anymore."

Netanyahu's office said on Saturday he would not make a planned trip to New York on June 21 because of sensitive impending legislation. Local media said he did not want to risk meeting President Bill Clinton with the crisis raging.
Diplomats at the European Union summit in Amsterdam said leaders would consider an appeal to the peoples of the Middle East to press their governments to resume stalled peace talks.

They said France had offered a draft statement, voicing deep concern at the impasse in the Arab-Israeli peace process and at the potential threat to peace, which EU foreign ministers would study on Monday night and leaders could issue on Tuesday.
Late on Sunday, the Palestinian news agency WAFA said Arafat had given EU peace envoy Miguel Angel Moratinos a letter for the Amsterdam summit calling on the EU to save the peace process.
